reporting-org.narrative: Wageningen University & Research - Stichting Wageningen Research

title.narrative: Integrated Seed Sector Development (ISSD) Plus

description.narrative: Small and medium-scale farmers are the ultimate beneficiaries. The expectation is that some 300,000 households will increase productivity, income and resilience, based on the assumption that these farmers will increase productivity from the use of quality seed for crop production. A specific focus is given to gender and youth. Direct beneficiaries are the Local Seed Business (LSB) members and by the end of the project some 7500 LSB members are expected to have benefited from the production and marketing of Quality Declared Seed (QDS), in terms of increased productivity and income. In addition to this, some 100 vegetable sector professionals will be trained as trainers (TOT), and some 20,000 small holder farmers in will be trained in good vegetable production, using quality vegetable seed of advanced varieties. Four vegetable seed companies will also directly benefit from the project, since they will be given a grant for developing demonstration plots. A specific focus is given to gender and youth under project implementation.

The ISSD Plus project runs from 2016 to 2020 and builds on the previous ISSD project (2012-2016). It operates in the East, South Western Highlands (Kigezi area), Western Highlands (Rwenzori area), South Western, Northern Zone and also has a presence in the West Nile zone agro-ecological zone. The project implements its activities through teams in the Zonal Agricultural Research and Development institutes (ZARDIs) of the National Agricultural Research Organisation (NARO). The ZARDIs involved in the project include; Buginyanya ZARDI for the East; Rwebitaba ZARDI for the Rwenzori area; Mbarara ZARDI for the South West and South Western Highlands; Ngetta ZARDI for the North and West Nile zone.

The overall goal of the project is to contribute to increased incomes of smallholder farmer households and improved household food and nutrition security. Special attention is given to women and youth in increasing income. The project goal will be realized through increased productivity of field and vegetable crops (Intermediate Result). For field crops, increased productivity provides increased income and improved food security through existing and growing markets. The productivity increase results from the increased use of quality seed by small and medium-scale farmers (component 1). Quality seed use will be promoted through publicity and demonstration campaigns and proximity marketing efforts. Proximity marketing focuses on increasing farmers’ access to seed close to areas they easily reach. To satisfy the increasing quality seed demand, local seed businesses (LSBs) are supported to produce and market Quality Declared Seed (component 2). This means in practice that the project scales the LSB approach based on the experiences of the previous ISSD Uganda project (2012-2016). To assure that LSBs are able to perform well, their access to early generation seed is being improved (component 3). The ISSD Plus project has a specific objective on vegetable sector development (component 4). In the vegetable sector, the access to EGS is not an issue, as vegetable seed companies have privately bred varieties integrating EGS into their commercial seed production chain. The project is therefore intervening to improve the access of vegetable producers to high quality seed and seedlings, through the introduction of improved varieties and improving farmers’ skills in vegetable production. By training vegetable growers, they will become able to take advantage of high quality seed and seedlings, and increase their productivity (Intermediate Result).

participating-org.narrative: Buginyanya Zonal Agricultural Research and Development institute (ZARDI)
Kachwekano Zonal Agricultural Research and Development institute
Mbarara Zonal Agricultural Research and Development institute (ZARDI)
Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries (MAAIF)
Ngetta Zonal Agricultural Research and Development institute (ZARDI)
Rwebitaba Zonal Agricultural Research and Development institute (ZARDI)

mailing-address.narrative: The Integrated Seed Sector Development Plus Programme in Uganda, Studio House, Plot 5 Bandali Rise, Bugolobi P. O. Box 20106, Kampala

recipient-country.narrative: Uganda’s population of 35 million is growing by 3% per annum and 75% is below the age of 30. 77% of the employed population works in agriculture, forestry and fishing. Uganda is making progress with regard to the Millennium Development Goals; absolute poverty dropped from 25% in 2010 to 20% in 2013, and prevalence of underweight children under five has declined from 26% in 1999 to 14% in 2013 (MDG report, 2013). The rural-urban divide is however expanding mostly as a result of unevenly distributed socio-economic infrastructure such as road networks, access to markets, health and educational services and private sector investments. Official unemployment in Uganda is steadily increasing, from 1.9% in 2010 to 9.4% in 2013 (UBOS, National Household Survey, 2012/13). Particularly the youth unemployment of 32.2 % is worrisome (UBOS Youth Employment Report, 2012). While the agricultural sector is central to the country’s development agenda, its absorption of youth is low. Youth are increasingly shunning rural areas to access better services and livelihood options in urban areas (AfDB, OECD, UNPD, 2015, Uganda 2015, African Economic Outlook). Although the urban – rural divide is growing, urbanization does at the same time present opportunities for rural development. There is a growing demand for food for those not involved in agricultural production. Furthermore, urban food patterns are diversifying, opening opportunities for value addition and food crop quality diversification and niche crops such as various vegetables as well as oil crops. Combined with growing trade in the region, most notably towards South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo, there are strong incentives for farmers to become more market oriented and intensify their production. The challenge is to support women and youth to equally take advantage of these opportunities. A thread to the growth of the food and agriculture sector is posed by climate change and declining soil fertility. With diminishing reliability of rainfall pattern, farming and market systems have to be adapted to maintain national food self-sufficiency, improve national food and nutrition security, and at the same time increase export volumes to contribute to economic development. This requires efforts to support Ugandan producers in the environmental and economic sustainable intensification of their production. The use of high quality seed is a prerequisite for sustainable intensification of production, without it efficient use of resources such as land, labour, capital and soil nutrients is not possible.

sector.narrative: Food markets provide unprecedented opportunities for rural development. Subsistence farmers who produce primarily for their own consumption have become rare. Almost invariably Ugandan farmers are aiming to produce a marketable surplus to derive an income, while simultaneously satisfying their household food needs. At the same time however, the market orientation of agricultural production is not being accompanied by optimal seed use practices. A survey of the ISSD Uganda project (2016) clearly showed the mismatch between production objectives of Ugandan farmers and their seed use practices. It demonstrates that Ugandan farmers still follow seed use practices of subsistence oriented farmers. Currently farmers only regularly replace their hybrid maize and vegetable seed. They mainly rely on their own farm-saved seed. Over 30% of the farmers indicate to never replace their bean, oilseed, root and tuber and open pollinated cereal seed. If farmers replace their seed from an outside source, the most important sources are grain markets and their neighbours. Only a very small proportion of seed planted comes from a commercial seed provider.

policy-marker.narrative: In order to address challenges in the seed sector environment, the project contributes to addressing seed sector and vegetable sector bottlenecks as identified by stakeholders. In addition, work is done to lobby and advocate for cabinet approval of the national seed policy, and to support options for QDS, EGS and vegetables. Multi-Stakeholder Processes (MSPs) are organised at zonal and national (including national seed stakeholder meetings) since the bottlenecks in the seed can only be addressed by a variety of stakeholders. In addition to this, LSB out scaling through partners and the training of trainers for vegetable sector professionals are also intended to be embedded in relevant existing institutions.

title.narrative: ISSD Plus project brochure

description.narrative: The brochure provides an overview of what the ISSD Plus project is about.

title.narrative: 2018 Annual narrative IATI report

description.narrative: Report is a summary of major achievements at output, outcome and goal level for the ISSD Plus project. This is based on the approved logframe document

title.narrative: More farmers take on the QDS production and marketing business

description.narrative: An LSB has 20-30 members who contribute to production of QDS. They work together as a business entity to enjoy economies of scale

title.narrative: Number of LSB farmers producing and selling QDS

description.narrative: Number of farmers involved in production of quality declared seed (QDS). An LSB has approximately 20-30 farmers

title.narrative: Foundation seed demand by seed producers is sufficiently met

description.narrative: Early generation seed is an essential input into the seed sector. Foundation seed production is the Achilles heel of seed production; if the supply is low and quality of Foundation seed is poor, seed cannot be effectively multiplied and its quality will also be poor. To achieve better conditions, the project will look at three options including production of foundation seed by LSBs, ZARDIs and the Foundation seed enterprise. This coupled with a quality assurance structure will facilitate quality seed production

title.narrative: Percentage of LSB foundation seed demand met

description.narrative: Information is mathematically derived as the Difference between volume of foundation seed booked and purchased. Information is picked from production records of QDS producers.

title.narrative: Sufficient volumes of quality foundation seed is produced for demanded crop varieties

description.narrative: Foundation seed is an essential input into the seed sector. Foundation seed production is the Achilles heel of seed production; if the supply is low and quality of EGS is poor, seed cannot be effectively multiplied and its quality will also be poor. To achieve better conditions, the project will look at three options including production of foundation seed by LSBs, ZARDIs and the Foundation seed enterprise

title.narrative: Volume of foundation seed produced annually by the Foundation Seed Enterprise, selected ZARDIs and LSBs

description.narrative: Information is picked from production records of the Foundation Seed Enterprise, selected ZARDIs and LSBs; It is assumed that; The legal requirements for the FSE are met ; NARO provides the breeder material in the required amounts and quality; MAAIF provides the necessary quality assurance services

title.narrative: More food is produced as a result of using quality seed

description.narrative: Keeping all other factors constant, the increased use of quality seed by smallholder farmers will lead to increased productivity per unit area. Larger volumes of food will therefore be produced for consumption and sale

title.narrative: Additional agricultural production of grain equivalent as a result of using quality seed

description.narrative: Mathematically derived based on volume of seed sold & yield difference between home saved seed and quality seed, per crop; volume aggregated for all crops. It is assumed that farmers produce more food with the use of quality seed, which will partly be used for home consumption and partly to sell for income. It is also assumed that agricultural growth will take place as a result of increased productivity based on improved seed subsector

title.narrative: Foundation seed produced meets minimum standards

description.narrative: One of the constraints related to the current practice of EGS production is that the quality of EGS produced is unchecked. To create favourable conditions for quality EGS, the ISSD Plus project will support the National Agricultural Research Organisation (NARO), in collaboration with partners like Ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries (MAAIF), to address the poorly regulated and coordinated structure of EGS production

title.narrative: Proportion of foundation seed meeting minimum standards

description.narrative: Indicator information is based on field inspection results of the foundation seed as provided by the Ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries (National Seed Certification Services). It is assumed that MAAIF provides the necessary quality assurance services

title.narrative: Foundation seed produced is inspected to ensure quality during field production

description.narrative: One of the constraints related to the current practice of Foundation seed production is that the quality of Foundation seed produced is unchecked. To create favourable conditions for quality Foundation seed production, the ISSD Plus project will support the National Agricultural Research Organisation (NARO), in collaboration with partners like Ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries (MAAIF), to address the poorly regulated and coordinated structure of Foundation seed production

title.narrative: Proportion of foundation seed fields inspected

description.narrative: Information is picked from production records of the Foundation Seed Enterprise, selected ZARDIs and LSBs; It is assumed that; MAAIF provides the necessary quality assurance services. It is assumed that MAAIF provides the necessary quality assurance services

title.narrative: Households increase their productivity, income and resilience

description.narrative: Quality seed alone has an impact on agricultural productivity, even if other practices remain the same. Ugandan small and medium-scale farmers will be able to intensify their productivity to be able to produce and market a larger surplus by using quality seed. The degree of the marketable surplus however depends on other factors than those controlled by the ISSD Plus project alone.

title.narrative: Number of households improving their productivity and income by using quality seed

description.narrative: Mathematically calculated based on the average seed use per farmer per season and quantity of seed sold over the year

title.narrative: Production of iron rich food increases

description.narrative: Some LSBs are involved in production of seed for improved varieties enhanced with iron nutrients. This will lead to increased production of iron rich food needed by the sick, mothers and children

title.narrative: Amount of food produced that prevents and treats iron deficiencies in Uganda (MT)

description.narrative: Mathematically calculated based on the amount of seed sold for iron rich bean varieties, seed rate for beans and average yield of beans per acre

title.narrative: Production of vitamin A rich food increases

description.narrative: Some LSBs are involved in production of seed for improved varieties enhanced with the Vitamin A nutrient. This will lead to increased production of Vitamin A rich food needed by deficient members of the population

title.narrative: Amount of food produced that prevents and treats Vitamin A deficiencies in Uganda (MT)

description.narrative: Mathematically calculated based on the quantity of planting materials sold for sweet potato varieties rich in vitamin A, seed rate for sweet potato and average yield of sweet potato per acre

title.narrative: More volumes QDS are produced for locally preferred varieties of legumes and cereal crops

description.narrative: The concluded ISSD Uganda project effectively demonstrated that through the initiation, training and coaching of farmer groups organised as local seed businesses in QDS seed production the local availability of quality seed can be much improved. New groups will therefore be established in new zones and old groups will be supported to increase their productivity levels per unit area and to improve their business environment. Depending on the demand within communities, production of QDS for seeded crops will raise

title.narrative: Quantity of QDS produced for legumes, cereal and oil crops (MT)

description.narrative: Indicator is based on the amount of QDS produced by LSBs for root and tuber crops including beans, cowpeas, finger millet, greengram, groundnut, pasture, pigeon pea, rice, simsim, sorghum and soybean,

title.narrative: More volumes QDS are produced for locally preferred varieties of root and tuber crops

description.narrative: The concluded ISSD Uganda project effectively demonstrated that through the initiation, training and coaching of farmer groups organised as local seed businesses in QDS seed production the local availability of quality seed can be much improved. New groups will therefore be established in new zones and old groups will be supported to increase their productivity levels per unit area and to improve their business environment. Depending on the demand within communities, production of QDS for seeded crops will raise

title.narrative: Quantity of QDS produced for root and tuber crops (MT)

description.narrative: Indicator is based on the amount of QDS produced by LSBs for root and tuber crops including sweet potato, cassava and potato.

title.narrative: QDS samples comply with set minimum standards of quality seed

description.narrative: The development of the decentralised and simplified quality assurance system has been crucial for the professionalization of the local seed businesses in the intervention zones of the current ISSD Uganda project. This includes roll out of field inspection by District Agricultural Officers and decentralisation of seed testing to zonal lab

title.narrative: Percentage of seed samples complying with set minimum QDS quality standards

description.narrative: Indicator information is based on QDS test results provided by the Ministry of Agriculture Animal Industry and Fisheries (National Seed Certification Services)

title.narrative: Strengthen seed sector institutions and environment by putting more efforts in stamping out fake seed

description.narrative: The existence of fake seed in the seed market is one of the challenges identified by smallholder farmers. This challenge can be dealt with institutionally if all stakeholders put effort in stamping the sale of fake seed

title.narrative: Efforts by different stakeholders to stamp out fake seed

description.narrative: The African Seed Access Index (TASAI) tracks the number of cases of fake seed reported to government authorities each year.This is picked at the start and end of the project

title.narrative: Local Seed Business (LSB) methodology and Vegetable trainings in the high input-high output vegetable production system embedded in existing institutions

description.narrative: The project will work towards having the vegetable training of Trainers and LSB methodology embedded in other institutions to contribute to scaling of the approaches and sustainability

title.narrative: Number of institutions approached for embedding of the LSB methodology and the vegetable trainings

description.narrative: The project will approach institutions with the potential to take on scaling of the LSB methodology and the training of trainers for vegetable sector professionals in their mandate

title.narrative: Gender empowerment by engaging women in top leadership positions of an LSB

description.narrative: Through the ISSD Plus project the LSB members will professionalise their existing or emerging seed production and marketing efforts. This presents an opportunity for 55% of the members who are women as noted from the concluded ISSD project. To increase their participation in the seed business, efforts are made to involve them in top leadership positions of the groups e.g. LSB chairperson, Vice Chairperson, Secretary or chairperson of the LSB committees including, Production, internal quality control, finance and marketing

title.narrative: Number of women in LSBs top leadership positions (LSB chairperson, committee chairperson)

description.narrative: Gender Action Learning methodology trainings encourage more women to take up top leadership roles; The trainings improve men’s attitudes towards women as leaders

title.narrative: Vegetable farmers supported to take on the high input-high output vegetable production system

description.narrative: Vegetable farmers currently have limited access to quality seed of improved varieties which is considered to be high input but leading to high output for a farmer. Four seed companies therefore have the ambition to increase the uptake of varieties with superior productivity and quality potential by vegetable producers. One of the avenues through these varieties are promoted under the project are the vegetable demonstrations on which farmer field days are held

title.narrative: Number of vegetable producers sensitised on advanced vegetable seed use at the vegetable demonstration sites

description.narrative: Vegetable producers are sensitised on the value of using advanced vegetable varieties. They also receive training on the high-input high-output vegetable production system during field days at the demos

title.narrative: More land under crop production is planted with quality seed

description.narrative: With increased production of QDS by LSBs and adoption by smallholder farmers, more land will be planted with quality seed

title.narrative: Area planted with quality seed (acres)

description.narrative: Area planted with quality seed enhances ecologically sustainable food systems. The indicator is mathematically derived based on the seed rate and the volumes of seed sold per crop, area aggregated for all crops. It is assumed that farmers desire to use good agronomic practices
